accussed_details.name: Muhammad Aslam
allegation: Improper grant of land on Harap tenure
accussed_details.evidence: Certificate from Headmaster, Government Primary School, Golarchi

accussed_details.name: Muhammad Malik
allegation: Improper grant of land on Harap tenure
accussed_details.reason: Settled in Sind in the same year, unable to fulfill Harap tenure conditions

complaint_summary: Muhammad Rahim challenged the grant of land on Harap tenure to Muhammad Aslam and Muhammad Malik, citing improper eligibility and procedural errors. He argued that the Barrage Authorities failed to inform him about the grant cancellation.
investigation_summary: Evidence included certificates from X.E.N. Main Line Division and Headmaster of Government Primary School, Golarchi. Respondents failed to provide documentary proof of eligibility, including residence in Sind prior to land disposal.
judgment_summary: The court upheld the appeal, set aside the Revenue Officer's order, and directed arrears with penal interest to be recovered from the appellant. The land was re-granted to Muhammad Rahim.
punishment: Arrears with penal interest to be recovered from Muhammad Rahim.
Decision_or_verdict: Appeal allowed; land re-granted to appellant.
legal_arguments: Muhammad Rahim argued that the land was improperly granted to minors and non-Haris.
Respondents failed to prove eligibility under Harap tenure conditions.
Appellant cited water shortages and land location as reasons for non-cultivation.
assets: Land parcels B. No, 154/2, 3 and B. No, 153/2, 3

witness_statement.Muhammad Aslam: Admitted being a minor at the time of land grant.
witness_statement.Muhammad Malik: Failed to provide proof of eligibility under Harap tenure.

key_issues: Improper grant of land under Harap tenure.
Failure to inform appellant about grant cancellation.

legal_terms.Harap tenure: A type of land grant tenure requiring specific eligibility conditions.

summary_vector_notes: The case revolves around the improper grant of land under Harap tenure to minors and non-Haris. The appeal was allowed, the Revenue Officer's order was set aside, and the land was re-granted to the appellant. The court found that the appellant was not informed of the grant cancellation and that the respondents failed to meet eligibility conditions.
